definitions.definition: an activity involving a special skill at making things with your hands

examples.text: Sheep shearing is a highly skilled craft.
Subjects taught include art and craft, drama, and languages.
The men practised various traditional crafts, such as carving toys out of bone.

definitions.definition: all the skills needed for a particular activity

examples.text: chefs who learned their craft in top hotels
comedians plying their craft for an agency
a carpenter who is a real master of his craft

definitions.definition: skill in making people believe what you want them to believe

examples.text: He knew how to win by craft and diplomacy what he could not gain by force.
Hundreds of small craft bobbed around the liner as it steamed into the harbour.

wordOrigin: Old English cræft ‘strength, skill’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kracht, German Kraft, and Swedish kraft ‘strength’. Sense (4), originally in the expression small craft ‘small trading vessels’, may be elliptical, referring to vessels requiring a small amount of “craft” or skill to handle, as opposed to large ocean-going ships.
